briefing.opening: Good morning. Welcome to the climate briefing for February 12, 2026. Today's news will cover the escalating warnings of the climate crisis, various domestic and international efforts to address it, and the acceleration of renewable energy transition.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis and Domestic & International Warnings
sections.content: Warnings are simultaneously being raised domestically and internationally that climate change is progressing faster than anticipated, and that components of the Earth's system are moving out of their stable state [4, 22, 151]. Indeed, sea temperatures around the Korean Peninsula have risen by approximately 2-4 degrees Celsius compared to previous years and the average, leading to a sharp decline in catches of major seafood such as mackerel, hairtail, and flatfish, which in turn contributes to rising food prices [3, 7, 149]. Direct impacts are also evident in marine ecosystems, with the unfortunate news that the population of southern right whales, which had been gradually increasing, is now experiencing a sharp decline in breeding rates due to climate change [12]. Furthermore, research has been published indicating that climate change played a role in the devastating wildfires that occurred in Argentina and Chile, and international reports continue to highlight changes in the landscape of winter sports globally, with winter sports themselves being threatened [157, 160, 162, 164]. Amidst this situation, criticism has emerged that economics has failed to address the climate crisis, alongside concerns from the UK that public interest in Net Zero is significantly decreasing [152, 170, 173, 174].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Expanding Domestic and International Efforts for Carbon Neutrality
sections.content: Domestically, various policies and infrastructure development for achieving carbon neutrality are actively underway. In Seosan, the nation's largest Carbon Neutrality Demonstration Support Center has opened, exploring ways to utilize carbon as a resource and establishing itself as a hub for the CCU (Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage) industry [36, 50, 53, 54, 68, 69, 75, 84, 87, 90, 93, 95]. Several local governments, including Suwon City and Jincheon County, are making community-based efforts to create carbon-neutral green cities, such as recruiting citizen action groups and promoting ESG practices [33, 34, 35, 38, 41, 56, 58, 77, 78, 89, 99]. Notably, Seoul's Nowon District and Daegu City received 'Leadership (A-) grade' and the highest rating for two consecutive times, respectively, in the Global Covenant of Mayors for Climate & Energy (GCoM) assessment, thereby gaining international recognition for their implementation capabilities as leading carbon-neutral cities [37, 70, 79, 91]. Meanwhile, the European Union (EU) adopted carbon removal certification standards for the first time, aiming to prevent 'greenwashing' and establishing a regulatory milestone towards its 2050 carbon neutrality goal [73]. Positive international trends include an analysis showing that China's carbon dioxide emissions have exhibited a 'stagnation or decrease' trend for 21 months, and that coal-fired power generation has decreased in both China and India [175, 176].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Renewable Energy Transition and Community Participation
sections.content: To achieve carbon neutrality goals, the transition to renewable energy is accelerating, with a particular emphasis on the role of public institutions and local communities [49, 126]. 88 public institutions, including the Korea Environment Corporation, are participating in 'Public Institution K-RE100,' leading a major energy transition centered on renewable energy, and Korea Western Power is contributing to achieving carbon neutrality and energy transition through its 'K-RE100' implementation [88, 110, 111, 129]. Amidst arguments that mandating 100% renewable energy for data centers is a necessity, not an option, Gwangju City Council is also pushing for this [116, 127]. In local communities, voluntary movements are spreading, with Ulsan City's 'Haetbitmasil' (Sunlight Village) project enabling village communities to install and operate solar power plants, and Naju City also promoting resident-participatory renewable energy projects [121, 123, 130, 132]. Furthermore, private sector investment is active, with KB Financial completing the financial arrangement for the 29 trillion won 'Shinanu-i Offshore Wind Power Project,' marking the largest scale in the history of domestic renewable energy project financing [142].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Climate Change Adaptation and Ecosystem Conservation Activities
sections.content: Efforts for adaptation and ecosystem conservation to proactively respond to the impacts of climate change are also continuing across the nation. Wando County is accelerating the creation of 'blue carbon seagrass meadows' to restore marine ecosystems and secure carbon sinks, while Suncheon City has also initiated cooperation with Seoul National University and LG Electronics for tidal flat ecosystem restoration and climate change response [1, 6, 8, 15, 17, 19, 23, 25, 26, 63]. The Korea National Arboretum, in collaboration with national and public arboretums, is discussing the conservation of forest plant species vulnerable to climate change and exploring scientific and participatory adaptation strategies, including expanding their scope through citizen science [2, 9, 16]. Furthermore, efforts to strengthen adaptability in the agricultural and fisheries sectors are noteworthy, with Gyeongsangnam-do supporting climate change response aquaculture projects with 6.4 billion won, and Seogwipo, Jeju, incorporating climate change response and digital agricultural technologies into its core tangerine cultivation technology education [11, 13, 32]. Meanwhile, a study analyzing 40 years of data revealed that typhoons act as a 'lifeline' preventing drought in some regions, providing a new understanding of climate phenomena [14, 29, 31].

sections.title: ğŸ“° Key Research and Policy Trends Related to Climate Change
sections.content: Today's briefing presented international research findings on the necessity of re-evaluating our existing understanding of climate change, along with discussions on natural variability, solar forcing, model uncertainties, and policy implications [154]. Furthermore, the search for climate change adaptation strategies in specific sectors is active, including discussions on the impact of climate change on snow used in the Olympics [156]. Domestically, Representative Jo Ji-yeon introduced a 'Special Act on Climate Crisis Adaptation and Resilience Enhancement,' marking a move to establish legal and institutional foundations [27], and Sangju City's Carbon Neutrality Support Center held its 2025 performance evaluation committee, indicating ongoing assessment and review of policy implementation [82, 92, 98]. Meanwhile, news that the White House revoked the EPA's climate change endangerment finding highlighted international climate policy uncertainty [167], and discussions are also taking place on the economics of climate adaptation optimism [169].

briefing.closing: Today's briefing highlighted the severity of the climate crisis, but also offered glimpses of hope through proactive domestic and international efforts towards carbon neutrality and renewable energy transition, as well as various initiatives for ecosystem conservation. Addressing climate change is no longer an option but a necessity, and the sustained interest and participation of all of us are crucial. This concludes today's climate briefing. Thank you.

articles.title: Climate Change Bill Lands on Dinner Tables... Mackerel, Hairtail, Flatfish Prices All Rise
articles.original_title: ê¸°í›„ë³€í™” ì²­êµ¬ì„œ ê²°êµ­ ë°¥ìƒìœ¼ë¡œÂ·Â·Â·ê³ ë“±ì–´Â·ê°ˆì¹˜Â·ê´‘ì–´ ë‹¤ ì˜¤ë¥¸ë‹¤
articles.description: WWF Provided: Changes in marine ecosystems due to climate change are driving up grocery prices. An analysis indicates that food prices are continuously rising as seafood production decreases due to abnormal high water temperatures and heatwaves. According to the 'Sustainable Seafood Report' jointly published by WWF and E-Mart on the 12th, water temperatures around the Korean Peninsula have recently risen by approximately 2-4 degrees Celsius compared to previous years and the average.Â·Â·Â·

summary.phenomenon: Water temperatures around the Korean Peninsula have recently risen by approximately 2-4 degrees Celsius compared to previous years and the average, leading to a decrease in seafood production. According to the 'Sustainable Seafood Report' by WWF and E-Mart, these changes in marine ecosystems are contributing to rising grocery prices.
summary.cause: Changes in marine ecosystems due to climate change, such as abnormal high water temperatures and heatwaves, are identified as the scientific cause for the decrease in seafood production.
summary.outlook: Due to the decrease in seafood production, prices for food items such as mackerel, hairtail, and flatfish are expected to continue to rise.
